The Phil Ting man-wearing-a-receipt press conference stunt happened the second week of January. 

The whole receipt thing is ridiculous. CVS is ridiculous for its long receipts that are mostly special offers, and Ting is ridiculous for proposing a legislative fix.

text: Not *you specifically,* unless you didn't save, but the general *you* as in the universe. Or...whatever. I'm going to go now.

text: I would have larger reservations about news websites scrubbing their content after a period of time, if it's possible to archive stories and videos.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: I'm not. There one band — one — that primarily used MySpace as a host for their music, and I'm sad to see those exclusive tracks go away, but I'm a big proponent of social media websites periodically hitting the "reset" button. Think it's healthy. It's on you if you didn't save.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: Facebook has not made enough of an effort to launch their product in areas that are underserved by large market media but otherwise not classified as a news desert. That’s on Facebook, not on publishers.

text: "The car had more value to her than it did for me trading it in:" When a struggling nurse who risked losing her job without a car couldn't afford a down payment, a man transferred the title of his potential trade-in to her for nothing.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: "Talent is universal, but opportunity is not:" Meet Tanitoluwa Adewumi, an 8-year-old homeless refugee who just became New York State's chess champion. His family is in the process of seeking asylum.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: I've been listening to @RonFunches on his podcast over the last week or so. It's put me in a better mood, made me realize we need to do a better job focusing on the positives in life. It inspired the idea of a week-long positive news campaign. It'll be good for all of us.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text:
To kick off the process of leaving some of the negativity behind, I would encourage everyone to listen to @RonFunches on Conan's podcast: http://bit.ly/2HC9uPk 

And then subscribe to @RonFunches "Getting Better," a podcast largely about getting better
author: MatthewKeysLive

text:
There's been a lot of bad news floating around in the past few days — moreso than usual — and it's good for all of us to take a bit of a breather from that negativity.

So, this week, a different approach on this feed: A focus on good, positive news stories.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: "Hello brother," a man said just before an Australian citizen opened fire on a New Zealand mosque
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: You should direct your concerns to @muckrock, @documentcloud and @scribd. Your use case is exactly what these services are for.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: MuckRock and DocumentCloud promote transparency — until they don't. Their unilateral decision to remove newsworthy source material is extremely disappointing.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text:
Interestingly, @MuckRock and @DocumentCloud's decision to remove newsworthy material from their website comes during Sunshine Week.

Sunshine Week's tagline is "Your Right to Know." MuckRock and DocumentCloud's unilateral decision flies in the face of what that stands for.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: Journalists who use both @Scribd and @documentcloud/@MuckRock need to know that these services can, and will, unilaterally remove source material and other newsworthy content at their sole discretion with no advanced notice to you or your news organization.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: Both @Scribd and @documentcloud, owned by @MuckRock, have disabled access to the New Zealand terror attack suspect's manifesto, though the latter service admits their decision to remove the document was based on terms of service and policies that are not clear.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: There's been no official explanation from Twitter, but someone with knowledge of what happened said it was inadvertent.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text:
The bill was introduced by State Rep. Andrew McDaniel (@drurep150) in February, though news outlets are only now picking up on the proposed legislation. It has no co-sponsors.

text:
In New Zealand, politicians are pledging to ban semi-automatic firearms like the kind used in Friday's mass shooting at two mosques. 

The man who carried out the terror attack was licensed to carry a firearm there.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: The bill was introduced in late February. News outlets are just now picking up on the proposed legislation.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: Although his face has been widely distributed on social media and elsewhere, in New Zealand news outlets can be legally prohibited from revealing faces and names of suspects. http://bit.ly/2HzFfsw
author: MatthewKeysLive

text:
Brenton Tarrant, man charged with murder over terror attack in New Zealand, makes first court appearance.

"He was silent and repeatedly scanned the room looking around at media."

author: MatthewKeysLive

text:
A Missouri lawmaker introduced a bill called the "Militia Act" that would require residents between the ages of 18 and 35 to own an AR-15 rifle.

The same gun was used in Friday's terror attack in New Zealand.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: A shooting tailor-made for Internet consumption: Social media platforms now have a giant challenge ahead of them in determining how to prevent it from happening again — if they can at all
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: And last, I've reported through this platform for 12 years in large part because of the trust I have in Twitter. Thanks to Twitter's Communications, News Partnerships and Trust & Safety team for expediting a resolution to the problem once they became aware of it.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: To those who received my appeals via DM and on Facebook, thank you for your help and support. Special thanks to @CassandraRules for addressing the point directly on Twitter, one of the few reporters following me to do so.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text: It's still unclear why this happened, though early indications suggest it was inadvertent and not deliberate. I'm still waiting for an explanation and will pass it along once I know more.
author: MatthewKeysLive

text:
As some of you know, I had a small issue earlier this morning that prevented me from posting to Twitter. Seems I'm back online, and I appreciate Twitter's team for working diligently to help me through the problem. 

A recap of what happened:
author: MatthewKeysLive
